III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff qualifications
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
Description (a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Incident 1
When working, Former Staff 1 allowed Youth T to touch her
buttocks and breast.
Incident 2
Staff 2 gave Youth T a Breeze vape.
Incident 3
Unidentified staff drink alcohol at work.
Investigation Interviews:
I was assigned this investigation on 4/2/24. Complainant is
anonymous. In addition to allegations in this report, Complainant
alleged other possible licensing rule violations that were already
addressed in SIRs 2024SIC0001233, 2024SIC0001278 and
2024SIC0001286. Any activities that occurred or may have
occurred outside of the licensed facility were not investigated as
these are outside the scope of DCWL.
INCIDENT 1
I contacted Youth T’s Foster Care Worker on 4/3/24 and notified
her of the investigation assignment. She did not know Youth T’s
whereabouts and had no additional licensing concerns to report.
I interviewed Chief Administrator (CA) via phone on 4/3/24
regarding Former Staff 1’s employment history. She said Former
Staff 1 had only worked with youths for two weeks before she was
placed on administrative leave on 3/21/24 for possibly giving
Youth T her phone number and address. CA said she was unable
to determine if or how this happened, but officially terminated her
on 3/27/24 based on the staff’s “at-will” status at Wolverine
Center. CA denied witnessing Former Staff 1 allow Youth T to
touch her sexually. But when Youth T AWOLed on 3/25/24, she
2

gave police the former staff’s phone number and address in case
they wanted to follow up.
Initially Youth T could not be interviewed as he had AWOLed on
3/25/24 and his whereabouts were unknown.
On 4/3/24, Youth T was located and temporarily detained by the
Oak Park Police. According to Government Worker 1, Youth T
contacted police requesting help as he was in a hotel room
purchased by Former Staff 1. Police arrested Former Staff 1 on
an outstanding warrant and later charged her with Third-Degree
Criminal Sexual Conduct.
On 4/4/24 Government Worker 1 (in-person) and I (via conference
call) interviewed Youth T while he was at the police station. He
said he AWOLed from Wolverine Center on 3/25/24 and went to
Former Staff 1’s home in Warren. He stayed there until 3/31/24 or
4/1/24 at which time Former Staff 1 “put him in the car and drove
him to a hotel on 8 Mile Rd.” Asked why the former staff took him
to a hotel, Youth T stated, “Because the police were circling her
house.”
Youth T said he called the police from the hotel on 4/3/24 because
“uncomfortable stuff happened, and he didn’t like it.” I asked him
if “uncomfortable stuff” between he and Former Staff 1 also
happened inside Wolverine Center while she was working. Youth
T answered “Yes” but said he did not tell anyone at the facility
what happened.
On 4/4/24 Youth T was released from police custody to Foster
Care Worker who transported him to a residential facility on the
westside of the state.
While I was out of the office, a forensic interview of Youth T was
held at Voices on 4/18/24. Government Worker 1 observed the
interview and reported the following pertaining to Wolverine
Center:
Youth T told the forensic interviewer that Former Staff 1 touched
his buttocks inside the facility outside of his clothes. He would
not say how he got Former Staff 1’s phone number, and said he
got her address by looking at the outside of her house.
Former Staff 1 could not be reached by phone. On 4/24/24
Government Worker 1 attempted to interview Former Staff 1 on
the porch of her residence. She said Former Staff 1 screamed at
3

her that “nothing happened” and reluctantly accepted Government
Worker 1’s business card. The former staff told Government
Worker 1 that her attorney would be contacting her and slammed
the door.
I interviewed Youth Z jointly with Government Worker 1. He
denied witnessing anything unusual happened between Former
Staff 1 and Youth T but said he heard a rumor “they were doing
something strange.”
I interviewed Supervisor jointly with Government Worker 1 via
phone. He has worked at the facility for 22 years. On a date he
could not recall, Supervisor remembered he sent Former Staff 1
home “because Youth T was acting real strange when he was not
allowed to have her as a staff.” Asked why he sent her home,
Supervisor responded “I felt it was not safe for her…I didn’t see
her do anything, but Youth T was talking about harming people.”
Asked how Former Staff 1 reacted to being sent home, Supervisor
said “She asked me why and I told her it was unsafe. I don’t think
she felt good about it. Later I saw her standing outside (the
facility) across the street and thought it was strange when I had
asked her to go home.”
I interviewed Supervisor 2 jointly with Government Worker 1. She
was a direct care worker for eight months and then promoted to
supervisor in September 2023. Asked about Former Staff 1,
Supervisor 2 stated “I didn’t get a good feeling from her. Former
Staff 1’s feelings were unprofessional. I’d pull her (away) and
she’d somehow find her way back to Youth T. Her sense of
concern for him was too personal. She told me he had feelings for
her. I never saw her do anything except be in his presence. I
stressed to her the importance of keeping her distance. When
Youth T AWOLed he (allegedly) told an unidentified staff that he
was going to Former Staff 1’s house…She only worked here for
maybe three weeks. She had poor boundaries.”
INCIDENT 2
When interviewed Youth T said it was not Staff 2, but it was Staff
3 who gave him “vapes, weed buds, liquids and oils…free. I’d
keep it on my body or in my room. Once the vape dropped out of
my pocket and Supervisor and Supervisor 2 let me keep it. They
asked for it but then let me keep it because I was about to be
grown.”
I interviewed Staff 2 jointly with Government Worker 1. He has
worked at the facility for five months. He denied giving Youth T
4

illicit substance or paraphernalia and denied seeing any other staff
give him this. Staff 2 did however, see Youth T drop a vape in the
facility. Before staff could confiscate it, he said “Youth T picked it
up, ran outdoors and hid it somewhere.” Staff 2 said he saw
Youth T vaping while he was off the premises without permission
(AWOL status). “He probably hid it outside and then picked it up,”
Staff 2 hypothesized.
Staff 3 arrived at the facility 45 minutes late for his scheduled
interview. I interviewed him jointly with Government Worker 1 via
phone. Staff 3 has worked at the facility for five months. He
denied giving Youth T illicit substances or paraphernalia and
denied seeing any other staff give him this. “When I saw Youth T,
he was always going to bed,” he remarked.
I interviewed Supervisor jointly with Government Worker 1 by
phone. He denied seeing or having any knowledge about Staff 2
or any other staff giving Youth T vapes. If he did, he said he
would report that staff. Supervisor denied ever seeing Youth T
drop a vape inside of the facility. “I never saw Youth T vaping
outside, but I heard he does when he AWOLs.”
I interviewed Supervisor 2 jointly with Government Worker 1. She
recalled a vape incident pertaining to Youth T outside of the gym.
Supervisor 2 denied allowing Youth T to keep a vape. “Absolutely
not,” she said. “It (vape) was discarded (in the office trash).
INCIDENT 3
Interviews:
Youth T, Youth N and Youth Z denied knowledge that staff drink
alcohol at work.
Supervisor, Supervisor 2, Staff 2 and Staff 3 denied knowledge of
any staff drinking alcohol at work.
Analysis Youth T AWOLed on 3/25/24 and went to Former Staff 1’s house
where sexual contact occurred between the two. Police charged
Former Staff 1 with Criminal Sexual Conduct and Government
Worker 1 deemed her unsuitable to work with children.
Former Staff 1 had only worked with youths at Wolverine Center
for about two weeks before Supervisors noticed she had an
unusual affinity toward Youth T. Later on 4/18/24 Youth T told a
forensic interviewer that Former Staff 1 touched his buttocks
outside of his clothes inside the facility. However, there are no
known witnesses and Former Staff 1 denied anything happened.
5

Wolverine Center staff were proactive and acted immediately to
prevent harm to Youth T and others inside the facility. Supervisor
2 reassigned her away from Youth T, Supervisor noticed Youth T
acting “strange” and sent Former Staff 1 home and CA placed her
on administrative leave on 3/21/24 and provided her address to
police ultimately assisting in her arrest.
While it is now clear that Former Staff 1 lacked the ability to
perform the duties of her assigned position, aside from poor
boundaries, no one witnessed her allow Youth T to touch her
buttocks or breast or saw her touch his buttocks inside the facility.
Due to facility staff noticing Former Staff 1’s suspicious behaviors
and intervening and CA responding proactively, harm to children
at the facility was prevented. Therefore, a citation against
Wolverine Center and a corrective action plan are not required.
(Violation Not Established)
There is no evidence to support that Staff 2 or any other staff gave
Youth T a vape.
(Violation Not Established)
There is no evidence that staff drink alcohol at work.
(Violation Not Established)
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youths access drugs and alcohol in the facility.
6

Investigation Interviews:
Youth T said he and Youth Z smoked vapes in the facility
together. He denied drinking alcohol or seeing any other youths
drink alcohol.
Youth Z denied smoking vapes inside the facility with Youth T and
that youth access drugs and/or alcohol in the facility.
Youth N denied youths have access to drugs or alcohol inside of
the facility.
Staff 2, Supervisor and Supervisor 2 denied youth have access to
drugs or alcohol inside of the facility.
Analysis There is no evidence youths access drugs or alcohol inside the
facility.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
